content: I finally figured out why I often get unexpected results from tab completing a user after typing @.
If you point the mouse at a username, that changes the cursor position, and then if you hit tab, it completes the one the mouse is pointing at.
That's true even if the mouse started out over the menu of possible completions and you didn't move it, or just barely moved it.

I think keyboard-based completion of a username shouldn't take mouse position into account. I don't know if anyone uses the mouse to point and click on a username, but it seems fine for that to work; it just shouldn't affect what you get when you hit tab to complete the name.

Something similar happens to me when I try to interact with the popup for topic completion. I.e. when I write #t-compil and then use arrows to select a stream in the popup, and then try to hit > to go to the list of topics in that stream, the moment I hit the shift key (to go from . to > for the keystroke), the Zulip UX interprets the strike of shift somehow as me saying “change the stream to whatever the mouse happens to be hovering over” (that is, if the mouse happened to be sitting in a position that overlaps where the stream popup showed up….
I’ve complained about this in the past (cannot remember where now) .. my solution has been to mostly try to avoid having the mouse over my zulip window...

pnkfelix said:

I’ve complained about this in the past (cannot remember where now) .. my solution has been to mostly try to avoid having the mouse over my zulip window...

Ah ha! I was complaining about it in #zulip > making links to topics pro-tip
but I hadn’t actually diagnosed it completely at that time. :)

Thanks for the report! I filed https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues/21018. Unfortunately, this behavior involves a bug in our third party typeahead library (forked from an unmaintained project), and may therefore not get fixed quickly.

thanks for filing it! Its something that’s relatively easy for me to work around, once I was aware of it. The biggest issue I think is that its a subtle behavior and the root cause is not always obvious (especially when you’re looking at things like the effect of hitting the shift key when one is in the process of trying to type >)
A fix for zulip/zulip#21018 has been merged, and should be deployed here in the next few days -- thanks again for the report!
@Alya Abbott Thank you as always for staying on top of the needs of Rust users in Zulip!
